articles.content:
Korean people's cause of reunification supported 
    Pyongyang, June 27 (KCNA) -- We hope that the north and the south of Korea would be independently and peacefully reunified at an early date, said Girija Prasad Koirala, prime minister of Nepal, on June 21 when meeting with the outgoing DPRK ambassador.
 He said he was pleased to see the improved relations between the north and the south and the affirmative changes for the reunification of the Korean peninsula taking place after the historic Pyongyang meeting and the publication of the June 15 North-South Joint Declaration.    
 The Nepalese government supports the principles of independence, peaceful reunification and great national unity laid down in the joint declaration and opposes the outside forces' interference in the  internal affairs of other countries, he declared.

articles.title: U.S. war moves condemned
articles.content:
U.S. war moves condemned 
    Pyongyang, June 27 (KCNA) -- Cha Sang Bo, vice-chairman of the General Association of Koreans in China, released a statement on Monday, which condemned the united states for ceaselessly committing war provocations against the DPRK, instead of drawing a serious lesson from its bitter defeat in the last Korean war and withdrawing its troops from South Korea.
 The U.S. imperialist aggression forces still refuse to abandon their wild ambition to deprive the Korean nation of its dignity and sovereignty and make a victim of it in realizing their strategy of world supremacy, and are getting ever more pronounced in massive arms buildup and reckless war moves, the statement noted, and said:    
 If the U.S. stages an invasion of the DPRK again, oblivious of its defeat in the 1950s, the Korean nation will give vent to its pent-up wrath and hatred and take thousand-fold revenge upon the aggressors for deep-rooted rancour against the Yankees without fail.
